bibl.title: Letter (English translation) from Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas to Philip Showalter Hench, August 11, 1940

div1.p: Rojas answers some of Hench's questions about the difficulties of research and the problems with the Cuban regime.

div1.head: Letter (English translation) from Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas to Philip Showalter Hench, August 11, 1940 (See Spanish original.)
div1.opener:
August 11, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
U. S. A.
My esteemed Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Please forgive the delay in answering your kind
letter. This is due to certain things I wanted to tell
you. My daughter and Miss Cabrera are doing what I told
them only that in this tropical climate everything is slow
and at the end of three months of trying to do what I wanted
I have not been able to get what I want.

About the trees, we have written to the Agronomic
Station of Santiago de las Vegas, The only place where they
know something about that because here there are no experts
as in other countries. From that place they have promised
us to come here to see about that but they have not done it.
Probably they are busy with politics as many people have been
during these last month and as they are Government employees
they have to do that.

About the article in the newspaper, we found in
the Sociedad Económica what I am enclosing, published in Eng-
lish from the newspaper La Lucha. In these copies there are
some loose notes which I am sending you, that is to say, tel-
ling you about the number of cases of yellow fever, death and
so forth. Tell me if you are interested. In the date you tell
me, that is November 21 of 1900, there is nothing in the news-
papers in Spanish. Nevertheless we are still looking for them.
On the other hand we have not seen the copies of the Havana Post
that interested you. The archive of this paper was burned in
1925 and the only public library in Havana that has a complete
collection is the National Library. This, though it seems un-
believable, has almost all its books in old boxes without
classification and not accessible to the public. There is a
very extreme carelessness in our government about the work of
culture. All the investigations I have tried to do have been
useless. They tell us that they would need a special employee
to look around those mountains of papers that we need but if
you consider those articles of capital interest we could find
the services of some employee.

Mr. Pogolotti returned already the original plans
of the farm. He himself has helped us in our investigations
in the National Library.

I have not seen Mr. Moran again. Miss Cabrera
spoke with him on the telephone and he promised to come to
see us but so far we have not had the pleasure of receiving
his visit.

I am very grateful to you for the photographs
that you had the kindness to send me. They will remind us
of the pleasant moments we spent with you all and we hope that
you come again. About what you promise me about Camp Lazear,
is of the greatest interest to me, as much for its historical
value as for its sentimental one. For this kindness I wish
to thank you, also for your interest in finding out about the
real situation of the Campamento Lazear, because that is a true
honor for us being in the farms of San José.

We are waiting for the notes that you told us to
add to the data which you wish about the history of the farm
and something more if we remember. You may be sure that it
will be a pleasure for us to serve you in everything we can.
Therefore do not hesitate to occupy us or write to us as many
times as you think it necessary.

We are in San José spending the summer where the
temperature is more bearable than in Vedado because this year
the heat has been excessive.

Give Mrs. Hench our affectionate greetings and ask
her forgiveness for me because I delayed answering and thank-
ing you for sending the flowers.

We pray for the health of your son and I hope he
is now very well.

Please give us news from you and keep us posted
about your investigations. With regards from my daughter
and from Miss Cabrera, I send you the expression of my sin-
cere friendship.
div1.closer: (Signed) Maria Teresa L. Vda. de Rojas (Translated by Miss Montes)
